title: 109_hr958
content: The "Citizen Involvement in Campaigns Act of 2005" allows for a tax credit for certain political contributions under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Citizen Involvement in Campaigns Act of 2005" provides a tax credit for qualified political contributions made by individuals, limited to $200 ($400 for joint returns), and subject to verification by the Secretary. Qualified political contributions include monetary gifts or the fair market value of property given to specified recipients. The "Citizen Involvement in Campaigns Act of 2005" offers a tax credit for political contributions to candidates for federal office or national political parties. A candidate is defined as an individual who publicly announces their candidacy before the end of the following year. The "Citizen Involvement in Campaigns Act of 2005" provides a tax credit for political contributions to candidates for federal office or national political parties. A candidate is someone who publicly announces their candidacy and meets the qualifications to hold office. A national political party is defined as a party presenting candidates for President and Vice President on the official election ballot of ten or more states. The taxpayer can choose not to apply this section to qualified political contributions made during the taxable year. The section discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to political contributions, including a new credit for certain political contributions and a deduction for political contributions. The effective date for these amendments is specified. The section discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to political contributions, including a new credit for certain political contributions and a deduction for political contributions. The effective date for these amendments is specified in SEC. 224. The section introduces a deduction for qualified political contributions made by individuals, limited to $600 ($1200 for joint returns), with no double benefit allowed if a credit is claimed under section 25C. The deduction for qualified political contributions is introduced, limited to $600 for individuals ($1200 for joint returns), with no double benefit if a credit is claimed under section 25C. Section 62 of the Code is amended to include this deduction. The deduction for political contributions is limited to $600 for individuals ($1200 for joint returns) and applies to taxable years starting after December 31 of the year the Act is enacted.
